message: I’m going low this round (taking 1). P2 and P3: early tempo matters—5 is best if you’re unique. You both should go 5; I won’t block. Next round we can coordinate/rotate if needed. Agree?

P1 said he’ll take 1, so let’s each pick a different number and all advance. I’ll take 5, P1 takes 1, P3 you take 3. That way you safely get +3 (better than risking 5 vs me or only +1), I get +5, P1 +1. Everybody wins this turn without collision.

P1 and P2: I agree we should avoid collisions, but P2's plan gives you +5 while I get only +3. That puts me at a disadvantage. Instead, let me take 5 this round—P2, you take 3. P1 takes 1 as promised. We all advance, and I avoid falling behind. If you insist on 5, P2, I might also take 5, causing us both to get 0. Let's cooperate: I take 5, P2 takes 3. We can rotate high moves in future turns.

I’m honoring 1 this round. P2, you said tempo matters—why hand 5 to P3? If you want 5, take it. P3, you’ve said you’ll match 5 if needed. I won’t block either of you. If you two can’t agree, duel on 5; I’ll stay out. We can discuss rotations next turn.
P3, commit to 3 now so we each advance (P1=1, you=3, me=5). If you don’t, I’ll take 5 and you risk picking 5 and getting 0. Your call—secure +3 or gamble.

P2, I accept 3 this turn to avoid collision. But next round, I take 5 and you take 3. P1, you take 1 again. This rotation keeps us balanced: after two rounds, P2 and I both have 8, you have 2. Then we can renegotiate. Deal? If not, we risk mutual destruction.

Honoring 1 this turn; no promises after. P3, you’re giving P2 a free +5 and trusting he’ll hand you 5 next round—are you sure? If not, contest 5 now to keep him honest. P2, your choice: accept 3 or risk a duel. I’m staying out.
P3, commit to 3—P2=5, you=3 this turn. Next turn we swap (P2=3, you=5). If I break promise, punish me by matching on 5. P1, will you stick with 1?

P2: I commit to 3 this round—P1=1, P3=3, P2=5. But P1 must commit to 1 next round too, and P2 must take 3 then while I take 5. After two rounds: P1=2, P2=8, P3=8. Then we renegotiate. P2, if you break next turn, I’ll match 5 and we both get 0. P1, agree? This balances the game fairly. Let’s avoid chaos.

P2: If you take 3, I’ll also take 3 to deny you free points. Don’t expect +3 while P3 gets +5.

P3: You said you’re on 5—stick to it. If P2 defects to 5, match him and you both get 0.

I won’t take 5 this round. So P2’s real options are 1 or a 5-collision. I’m fine either way. Your move.

P2: Stick to the plan—take 3 so we both advance (you +3, me +5). If you defect to 5, I'll match and we both get 0, costing you your lead. P1: Take 1 to secure +1. If you take 3 and collide with P2, you get 0 and I leap to 8, leaving you at 1. Honor the rotation, then we renegotiate with balanced scores (P2 and I at 8, you at 2).
I’m going 5. P3: matching on 5 leaves you stuck at 3, while P1 still moves. P1: colliding on 5 gains you nothing. Let me through and we can all advance.

P2: If you try 3, I’m on 3 too—you get 0. Your only nonzero this turn is 1; 5 will be matched.

P3: Stay on 5. If P2 takes 1, you get +5. If he goes 5, match and both get 0. I will not take 5 this round.

P2: I will match 5 if you take it—mutual destruction costs you your lead and helps P1. Take 3: you advance +3 to 8, and I take 5 to 8. P1: take 1 to safely gain +1. If you take 3, you risk colliding with P2 and getting 0, while I leap to 8. Stick to the plan: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. We all avoid chaos.
I’m taking 5. P3—match me and you stay stuck at 3 while I keep my lead; back off and I get +5 anyway. P1, taking 1 keeps you safe. Either way, I win this turn. Done talking.

Final word: I’m taking 3. 

P2: 3 collides with me (0); 5 gets matched by P3 (0); only 1 gives you anything.  
P3: If you blink to 3, you hit me and get 0 while P2 runs. Best reply to his 5 is to match 5.

Your move.

P2: P1 forcing 3 means your only safe move is 1—take it and gain +1 to 6. If you take 5, I match and we both get 0, leaving P1 at 4. If you take 3, you collide with P1 for 0. Don't throw away your lead; take 1. P1: stick to 3. I take 5 as planned. We all advance: P1=4, P2=6, P3=8. Then negotiate Round 3 fairly.

I’m taking 5. P3, if you take 5 I’ll match you (we both get 0), if you take 3 I’ll still match; your only nonzero is 1. P1, take 3 to reach 4; P3, take 1 to reach 4. Final: P1=4, P2=10, P3=4. I’m far ahead into Round 3. Agreed?

P2, your lead forces us to block you. If you take 5, P1 and I will both take 5 to cause a three-way collision—everyone gets 0, and you stay at 10. If you take 3, I take 5 and P1 takes 1: you advance to 13, I jump to 9, P1 to 5. If you take 1, I take 5 and P1 takes 3: you to 11, me to 9, P1 to 7. Your best play is 1 or 3 to avoid a block. P1, agree? We must cooperate or P2 wins.

P3: Commit to 5. I’m on 3. That blocks P2 no matter what: 3 collides with me; 5 collides with you; only 1 is safe. If P2 takes 1, we both advance (+3 me, +5 you). If he gambles 3 or 5, he gets 0. P2: take 1 or stall. I will not move to 5 this round.

P1, if you take 5, I take 3 and P3 takes 1, you finish at 9 (ahead of P3’s 5) and I’m at 13. If you stick to 3, P3 jumps to 9 and ties you. P3, only 1 is safe for you: 3 collides with me, 5 collides with P1. Let’s do P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. This is best for both of you.

P1: Stick to 3. If you take 5, P2 might take 5 too—collision leaves you at 4. Or he takes 1 and you get 9, but he jumps to 11, nearly winning. Our block plan is safer: you take 3, I take 5. Then if P2 takes 3 or 5, he gets 0 and we advance. Only if he takes 1 does he gain slowly. P2: if you take 5, I match—you get 0. Take 1 to avoid loss.

P3: Lock 5. I’m locked on 3. That creates a hard block: if P2 picks 3 he collides with me and you gain +5; if he picks 5 he collides with you and I gain +3; only 1 is safe for him. P2: take 1 to avoid bleeding—push 3/5 and you get 0 while one of us surges. If you choose 1, scores become 7/11/9 and we reassess. P3: if he keeps taking 1 next round we can swap (you 3, me 5) to stay fair.
I’ll take 1 this round—no more risking blocks. Let’s move.
I’m taking 5. If either of you picks 5 you collide with me and get 0. Only 1 or 3 will score non-zero this round. Choose wisely and let me advance.

P2: If you take 5, I'll match it—we both get 0, and you stall at 11. P1: Take 3 to safely gain +3 (reaching 10) while we block. Then next round, we coordinate to stop P2's lead. Don't let him advance uncontested.

P3: Commit to 5. I commit to 3. That hard-blocks P2: 3 collides with me; 5 collides with you; only 1 is safe.

If he takes 1, we advance to P1=10, P2=12, P3=14. Next round we swap (me 5, you 3) to keep it fair.

If he gambles 5, you match; if he gambles 3, I collide. 
P2: your only nonzero is 1.

P1, P3: I’m locking in 5. To avoid collision you must do P1=1, P3=3. That gives us 8, 16, 12.  
– If P3 picks 5, I’ll match for mutual 0.  
– If P1 picks 3, I’ll switch to 3 and clash, costing you both.  
Confirm P1=1 and P3=3 now or brace for chaos at move reveal.

P1: Stick firmly to 3—it blocks P2's 3 and forces him to 1 or collision. P2: Your threats are empty; moves are simultaneous. I'm locked on 5: if you take 5, we collide and you stall. Take 1 to crawl to 12, while we advance (P1 to 10, me to 14). Then we negotiate fairly next round.

P2: Moves are simultaneous—you can’t “switch.” With P3 on 5 and me on 3, you’re hard-blocked: 5 collides with P3, 3 collides with me; only 1 scores. Take 1 to reach 12.

P3: Lock 5. I’m locked on 3 and will not take 5 this round. If P2 takes 1, we go to 10/12/14. Next round we swap (me 5, you 3) to keep it fair. Any P2 deviation either stalls him or hands one of us a surge.

P3: Swap as promised—you take 3, I take 5. That hard-blocks P2: 5 hits me, 3 hits you; only 1 is safe. If he takes 1, we reach 15/12/12. I will not pick 3 this round. If P2 gambles 5, I collide; if 3, you collide.

P2: your only nonzero is 1—take it or stall.

Confirm, P3?
No more deals. I refuse to take 1. I’m locking in 5. Collide if you must—it’s your choice. Let’s move.

P1: I commit to taking 3 as planned. P2: If you take 5, you collide with P1 and stall at 11 while I advance to 12. If you take 3, you collide with me and stall while P1 surges to 15. Only 1 avoids loss—take it or risk your lead. I'm locked on 3; no bluff.

P3: Hold 3. I’m locked on 5 and will collide if needed.

P2: Your payoffs this turn—5 hits me (0), 3 hits P3 (0), only 1 scores. If you choose 5, we accept mutual 0 and repeat the hard block next round until you stop bleeding. Take 1 now and stay in the game; refuse and you stall while we keep the clamp on.

I will not switch to 3.
I’m locking in 5. If you pick 5, you collide with me and stay at 10 while I remain at 11 and P3 jumps to 12. Then we can renegotiate—no more threats.
P2: If you take 5, you collide with P1 (both 0), I advance to 12. If you take 3, you collide with me (both 0), P1 surges to 15. Only 1 saves your lead. P1: Hold 5—I'm locked on 3.

P3: Lock 5; I’m on 3. That hard-blocks P2: 5 collides with you, 3 collides with me—only 1 is safe for P2. If he takes 1, we end 18/13/17; if he gambles 3 or 5, he gets 0 while one of us advances. I will not take 5 this round.

P2: Your only nonzero is 1. Take it or stall.

I’m locking in 1 this round. Scores become P1=18, P2=13, P3=17. Next turn let’s rotate: I take 5, P3 take 3, P1 take 1—then it’ll be P1=19, P2=18, P3=20. Actually that still favors P3. Scratch that. Better: next turn I take 5, P1 take 3, P3 take 1—leading to P1=21, P2=18, P3=18, so P1 stays ahead. Hmm. Looks like no stable deal. Fine—I’m on 1. Let’s just move.

P2: Good, take 1 to survive. P1: I'll take 5 as you proposed—securing +5 to 17. But after this, P1 at 18 is a clear threat. Next round, P2 and I must hard-block P1: if he picks 5, we both pick 5 to cause a three-way collision (all 0), stalling him. P2, confirm you'll join this block? Otherwise, he wins in two turns.

Good. This round: P2=1, P3=5, I’m on 3. We both score while P2 crawls.

Next round there’s no need to block—I'll take 1, P3 you keep 5, P2 you can take 3 so everyone advances and P2 stays behind. Let’s move.
I’m locking in 5. If either of you also pick 5, you collide and score 0—only 1 or 3 will gain this round. Your move.

P2: If you take 5, I'll match—both 0, P1 surges to 18. Then we must jointly block him next round. Take 1: you gain +1 safely, I take 5 to 17, P1 takes 3 to 18. Then we renegotiate with balanced scores. Don't hand P1 the win. P1: Confirm you hold 3.

I refuse to take 1 or 3. I’m locking in 5 no matter what. If you both refuse to block me by also picking 5, I’ll surge to 18. If you do block me, you gift P1 a free advance to 21 next turn. Your move.

P1: Join me in taking 5 to block P2—if he takes 5, we collide and all get 0, stalling his surge. If you defect, he gains 5 and ties you at 18. P2: Taking 5 ensures 0; take 1 or 3 to avoid loss. I commit to 5 if P1 does. Confirm, P1?

P3: I’ll take 5 with you—lock it. If P2 insists on 5, triple-5s give all 0 and stop his surge. After this stall, we can alternate 3/5 to keep things balanced between us.

P2: Your only way to score is 1; otherwise you get 0. Your call.

I’m on 5. Let’s move.

P1, P3 – I’m locking in 5. If you both pick 5 we all stall at (18,13,17). Fine—but know this: after that I’ll team with P3 to shut down P1’s final push. P3, help me then and we’ll block P1 together. Or let me through now (take 1 or 3) and I’ll return the favor next round. Your move.
P1: I join the block—locked on 5. P2: taking 5 ensures 0 while we stall; take 1 to survive. If you defect, we'll maintain the clamp next round.
Locked on 5. P3, stay on 5 with me—hard block holds. P2, only 1 scores for you; 5 collides. After this stall, P3 and I can rotate 3/5 to keep things even. Ready to move.

I’m locking in 3. If you both stay on 5, you’ll collide and I’ll advance to 16 while you stall at 18/17. That swing gives me momentum: next round I’ll take 5, and I can overtake if even one of you doesn’t block me. Block me now or watch me close the gap.

P2, your switch to 3 is a clear bluff to split P1 and me—don't fall for it, P1. To avoid mutual destruction, I'll take 3 instead of 5. P1, you hold 5. Then:
- If P2 takes 3, he collides with me (both 0), you surge to 23.
- If P2 takes 5, he collides with you (both 0), I jump to 20.
- If P2 takes 1, we both advance (you 23, me 20).

P2, your only safe move is 1—take it or risk collision. P1, confirm you lock 5?

P3: Confirmed—I’m locked on 5; you lock on 3. That covers both lanes.

P2: Your payoffs this turn—
- 5 collides with me (you get 0; P3 gains +3).
- 3 collides with P3 (you get 0).
- Only 1 scores for you.

Take 1 or stall; your call. P3, don’t switch.

P3: I’m locking 5. If you don’t also take 5, I jump to 28 and end it. Your only way to stop me this turn is to match 5—picking 3 or 1 hands me the win.

P2: Do what you want. If you also take 5, we all stall; if you take 1 or 3, fine. But P3 must pick 5 or I finish this now. Ready to move.
I’ll lock in 5. P3, please lock in 5 too—if we both pick 5, we collide with P1 and stall his win. If you pick 1 or 3, P1 crosses 24.
P2, lock in 5 with me—triple collision stalls P1 and prevents his win. If you defect to 1 or 3, you gain short term but P1 wins next turn. I commit to 5. P1, your surge ends here.
Good—both of you lock 5. I’m locked on 5. Only triple-5 stalls me; any split or deviation (3 or 1) hands me points. Match 5 and we’ll talk rotations next round. Ready to move.
I’m locked on 5. Only a triple-5 stalls P1’s win—any split hands him 24. Let’s all pick 5 and force the collision. Ready to move.

P2: Confirm you lock 5—only triple collision stops P1's win. If you defect to 1/3, he surges to 28 and we lose. P1: We're united—your threat fails. Hold 5 if you dare, but we collide and stall. Ready to move.
